title: 112_hr3139
content: The Act may be cited as the "District of Columbia National Disaster Insurance Protection Act" and establishes the District of Columbia Natural Disaster Protection Funds. The Act establishes the District of Columbia Natural Disaster Protection Funds, including provisions for qualified contributions to a natural disaster protection fund by insurance companies. The Act establishes the District of Columbia Natural Disaster Protection Funds, including provisions for qualified contributions to a natural disaster protection fund by insurance companies. Amendments are made to the tax code regarding gross income from assets held in the natural disaster protection fund. Amendments to the tax code exclude income, gain, loss, or deduction from assets in a natural disaster protection fund. Distributions from the fund are also addressed in the amendments. Amendments to the tax code exclude income, gain, loss, or deduction from assets in a natural disaster protection fund. Distributions made from the fund are also addressed in the amendments, including rules for excluding certain distributions from gross income. Amendments to the tax code address distributions from a natural disaster protection fund, excluding certain distributions from gross income. The fund consists of money, securities, or other property held by a qualified insurance company. The natural disaster protection fund, referred to as the 'fund,' is money, securities, or property held by a qualified insurance company in a segregated account designated as such and held in a licensed bank in the District of Columbia. The 'fund' is held by a qualified insurance company in a segregated account in a licensed bank in the District of Columbia, regulated by the Comptroller of the Currency or the District of Columbia Commissioner of Insurance, Securities, and Banking. The assets in the fund must be invested according to investment requirements for insurance companies in the District of Columbia. The excess balance drawdown amount must be distributed to the qualified insurance company by the end of the following taxable year, and no assets from the fund can be paid out. The excess balance drawdown amount must be distributed to a qualified insurance company in the District of Columbia, subject to supervision by the Commissioner of Insurance, Securities, and Banking, by the end of the following taxable year. No assets from the fund can be paid out except for a qualified distribution. Insurance company in DC must be incorporated in DC, supervised by DC Commissioner of Insurance, maintain an office with at least 10 employees, pay taxes imposed by DC. Insurance companies in the District of Columbia must be incorporated in DC, supervised by the DC Commissioner of Insurance, maintain an office with at least 10 employees, and pay premium taxes, fees, and additional taxes imposed by the District of Columbia on natural catastrophic risk coverage written through the fund. Insurance companies in the District of Columbia must pay premium taxes on natural catastrophic risk coverage written through the fund at a rate set by DC, not exceeding the Federal excise tax rate on reinsurance contracts. The term 'qualified contribution' refers to a contribution to a fund established by a qualified insurance company, limited to the total of net premiums received during a taxable year for coverage of qualified losses. The term 'qualified contribution' refers to premiums or payments received during a taxable year for coverage of qualified losses, limited to the amount reasonably at risk for the payment of qualified losses insured through the fund. A 'qualified distribution' is any amount paid for such losses. The term 'qualified distribution' refers to payments made for qualified losses insured through the fund, less reinsurance on those risks, as determined actuarially on a multi-year basis. This includes payments for qualified losses under insurance or reinsurance contracts, spreading the risk of catastrophe loss, and excess balance drawdown amounts. The term 'qualified loss' refers to an insured loss on a United States risk that meets specific criteria, including payments for reinsurance, spreading the risk of catastrophe loss, excess balance drawdown amounts, administrative expenses related to fund maintenance and investment, and claims investigation and adjustments. The term 'qualified loss' refers to an insured loss on a United States risk that meets specific criteria related to events such as wind, earthquake, and flood. The events covered by a 'qualified loss' on a United States risk include wind (including hurricanes and tornados), earthquake (including any fire following), flood, tsunami or tidal wave, volcanic eruption, fire, hail, snow, ice, freezing, winter catastrophes, and pandemic or other public health catastrophe. The qualified losses on a United States risk include wind, earthquake, flood, tsunami, volcanic eruption, fire, hail, snow, ice, freezing, winter catastrophes, and pandemic or other public health catastrophe. Insured losses must meet certain criteria for a catastrophe designation. If insured losses exceed $1 billion industry-wide, the President declares a disaster, or a State's chief executive declares an emergency, a catastrophe designation may be warranted. If insured losses exceed $1 billion industry-wide, the President, Governor, or chief executive may declare a disaster or state of emergency. Additionally, a catastrophic industry-wide loss declaration by Property Claims Services unit of Insurance Services Office, Inc. may also trigger a catastrophe designation. The Property Claims Services unit of Insurance Services Office, Inc. declares a catastrophic industry-wide loss due to one or more events. The term 'excess balance drawdown amount' refers to the surplus of the fund balance over the total exposure to qualified losses under contracts issued by the qualified insurance company. The term 'United States risk' refers to hazards, risks, losses, or liabilities related to property or activities in the United States or its territories. Premiums and losses on certain Puerto Rican risks are excluded from this definition. The exclusion of premiums and losses on certain Puerto Rican risks from the definition of 'United States risk' is specified, regardless of any other provisions. Contributions in kind, such as property transfers, are also addressed. Contributions in kind to a fund are treated as a sale or exchange of property for its fair market value. Distributions in kind from a fund to a qualified insurance company are also addressed. Distributions of property other than money from a fund to a qualified insurance company are treated as a sale or exchange, with any gain or loss excluded from the gross income of the insurance company. The Secretary will prescribe necessary regulations for this subsection. The Secretary will prescribe regulations for subsection (d) of section 831 of the tax code, relating to additional tax on certain distributions from a Natural Disaster Protection Fund for qualified insurance companies. The tax code will impose a 20 percent tax on nonqualified distributions from a natural disaster protection fund made by qualified insurance companies. The tax code imposes a 20 percent tax on nonqualified distributions from a natural disaster protection fund by qualified insurance companies. Definitions for nonqualified distributions, qualified insurance company, and natural disaster protection fund are provided. Effective date for amendments is after December 31, 2011.
